qas.question: Which property of wood reveals the most about its quality?
In addition to lumber strength, what important indicator of wood's quality can be determined using specific gravity?
What measurement is expressed in mass per unit substance?
When wood dries and shrinks, what happens to its density?
When wood is described as "green," what does "green" mean?

context: The single most revealing property of wood as an indicator of wood quality is <a0_0>specific gravity<a0_0/> (Timell 1986), as both <a1_0>pulp yield<a1_0/> and lumber strength are determined by it. Specific gravity is the ratio of the mass of a substance to the mass of an equal volume of water; <a2_0>density<a2_0/> is the ratio of a mass of a quantity of a substance to the volume of that quantity and is expressed in mass per unit substance, e.g., grams per millilitre (g/cm3 or g/ml). The terms are essentially equivalent as long as the metric system is used. Upon drying, wood shrinks and its density <a3_0>increases<a3_0/>. Minimum values are associated with green (<a4_0>water-saturated<a4_0/>) wood and are referred to as basic specific gravity (Timell 1986).
